banner.title: What is Carbon Dioxide (CO₂)?
banner.description: Carbon Dioxide (CO₂) is a transparent gas and natural component of air, that acts as a greenhouse gas in the atmosphere. It is generally harmless in small quantities but can affect severely as the quantities rise, especially indoors where ventilation is low and indoor air cannot recirculate. Hence, it can impact sleep patterns, productivity, concentration levels, etc.

environment.title: How is it important in the environment?
environment.description1: CO₂ helps plants in the process of photosynthesis, a process through which plants make their food. Many animals and humans both depend on plants for their survival. Therefore photosynthesis is important for the survival of plants, animals, and humans.
environment.description2: CO₂ helps in trapping the heat and energy from the sun within the earths atmosphere. Because this helps in preventing the temperature from getting inhospitably cold and oceans from freezing into solid.

indoorLevels.title: What do indoor Carbon Dioxide (CO₂) levels say?
indoorLevels.description: CO₂ is commonly measured in PPM (Parts Per Million). ASHRAE (The American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers) recommended that carbon dioxide levels indoors should be maintained below 1000 ppm.

sources.title: Where does Carbon Dioxide (CO2) come from indoors?
sources.description: The main source of CO₂ indoors is respiration. Because as we inhale oxygen and release CO₂. In the modern age, homes are becoming more airtight, ventilation does not happen that frequently and fresh air cannot enter indoors. Many ventilation systems that are used nowadays recirculate the air indoors rather than bringing less CO₂ contaminated air from outdoors. As a result, the same air is recirculating and recirculating. Hence, this increases the carbon dioxide contamination indoors.

healthEffects.title: Health Effects
healthEffects.subtitle: High levels of CO₂ are responsible for

productivity.title: 1. Lower productivity
productivity.description: High CO₂ affects concentration and attention and in turn productivity.
productivity.imageAlt: low productivity due to high Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

sleep.title: 2. Disturbed sleep
sleep.description: When limits exceed, one can have difficulty in their sleeping patterns as well.
sleep.imageAlt: disturbing sleep due to high Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

bloodPressure.title: 3. Increased blood pressure & heart rate
bloodPressure.description: High CO₂ levels can trigger high BP problems due to the vasodilating effect.
bloodPressure.imageAlt: Increased blood pressure and heart rate

headache.title: 4. Headache
headache.description: CO₂ levels highly influence cerebral blood flow, which can cause headache problems.
headache.imageAlt: headache due to high Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

restlessness.title: 5. Restlessness
restlessness.description: Disorders such as hypercapnia can happen when CO₂ levels are high.
restlessness.imageAlt: restlessness due to high Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

dizziness.title: 6. Dizziness
dizziness.description: At high levels, CO₂ is known to cause dizziness, vertigo, and other symptoms.
dizziness.imageAlt: diziness due to high Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

tips.title: How to achieve the ideal Carbon Dioxide (CO2) levels indoors?
tips.subtitle: 10 tips to reduce carbon dioxide levels indoors:

ventilation.title: 1. Ventilation
ventilation.description: Makes it easy for the flow of air. Besides, it is the easiest and most economical way of reducing CO₂.

filtration.title: 2. Filtration
filtration.description: Air filters with activated carbon filters will help reduce the CO₂ concentration indoors.

plants.title: 3. Plants
plants.description: Indoor plants such as Snake Plant, Aloe vera, and money plant are known as the natural air filters.

decreasing.title: 4. Decreasing
decreasing.description: The number of people in a room also helps in reducing CO₂ concentrations.

monitor.title: 5. Use an air quality monitor
monitor.description: This will help in tracking and keeping a check on the CO₂ levels indoors.

emissions.title: 6. Control CO2 emissions
emissions.description: The usage of gas-powered heaters, coal burning, etc. must be controlled.

smoking.title: 7. Avoid smoking
smoking.description: Indoors as smoking contributes to the overall CO₂ concentrations indoors.

purification.title: 8. Air purification
purification.description: It does not help in reducing the CO₂ levels but filtered air is better than unfiltered air.

flames.title: 9. Open flames
flames.description: Must be limited as CO₂ is the primary pollutant emitted by an open fire, such as fireplaces.

fuelLeaks.title: 10. Keep a check on fuel leaks
fuelLeaks.description: CO₂ is released when fuels are burned improperly.
